articles.title: Earth's soil is drying up, and it could be irreversible

The team estimated that it added to global mean sea-level rise at a rate of 1.95 millimeters a year.

articles.title: Frontline Failure: Pakistan's Climate Vulnerability and Leadership Gap
articles.summary: Pakistan is the fifth most climate-vulnerable nation in the world. Pakistan's participation in COP negotiations has been largely reactive rather than strategic. Pakistan needs to take a more proactive role in climate policy making.

articles.title: Rising Temperatures in the Southern Ocean: Implications for Increased

articles.summary: As the Southern Ocean continues to warm, the stored heat from the atmosphere will be released back into the atmosphere, setting off a cascade of climatic changes worldwide. East Asia and Western U.S. will see an increase in precipitation during the summer months and in the winter. The new precipitation pattern could persist for as long as 150 years, independent of greenhouse gas mitigation efforts.

articles.title: Report shows bird population decline in United States
articles.summary: The 2025 State of the Birds Report shows bird populations are dropping across the board in the United States. Salinity levels vary by region and can affect everything from storm intensity to rainfall distribution. Climate change is causing the poles to melt and freshwater to enter the oceans.

Most March sightings have been in south-western areas of Britain, with some 25 hoopoes in the south of Ireland and 40 between Devon and Scilly on Wednesday.

articles.title: Kalle Olli: Green transition costly while giving it up costlier still

The likely main culprit is human-generated greenhouse gas emissions such as carbon dioxide, methane and nitrous oxide.

articles.title: Research shows that a majority of Christian religious leaders accept the reality of climate change but have never mentioned it to their congregations
articles.author: Stylianos Syropoulos
articles.summary: Nearly 90% of Christian religious leaders in the U.S. believe humans are driving climate change. When churchgoers learn this belief is widespread, they report taking steps to reduce its effects. Churchgoers who think their religious leaders don't believe humans cause climate change are less likely to discuss it with fellow congregants and less interested in attending events that address climate change or raise awareness of the issue.

articles.title: Research shows that a majority of Christian religious leaders accept the reality of climate change but have never mentioned it to their congregations

articles.title: Alaska Permafrost Thaw Risk Study Unveiled

articles.summary: As the region warms and permafrost thaws, infrastructure is threatened as the ground shifts beneath the built environment. articles.title: In Kenya, girls are sold into marriage to stave off starvation from drought
articles.author: Tom Parry

Aid groups say climate change is making droughts more frequent and deepening inequality.

The study makes the case that rapid decarbonisation is an environmental imperative and an economic necessity.

articles.title: The key question is: what is causing climate change?
